quoteFirst: He could not hear a sound save the gentle lap of the water against the side of the boat and the regular breathing of his brother.  And yet he knew that something was wrong.  He reached beneath his pillow and brought out his tiny flashlight and a glance at his watch told him than it was
title: The Lakewood boys in the South Sea islands
author: Wyman, L. P. (Levi Parker), 1873-1950

quoteFirst: Admiral made our signal to close;
quoteLast: , we began to engage; at fifty past one the Admiral made the signal to the Monarch to get into her station. At twelve past two he made the Alert signal to come within hail; half-past two he made the Royal Oak's signal to take the ship in tow that had struck her colours.
title: Memoirs and Correspondence of Admiral Lord de Saumarez. Vol II
author: Ross, John, Sir, 1777-1856

quoteFirst: In Japanese the texts of the _Nō_ dramas, all of which were written before the sixteenth century, are collected in a great work, the _Yokyoku Tsukai_, in which various editions give as many as two hundred and
quoteLast: hundred and sixty-two _utai_, as the librettos of the _Nō_ are called. Yet these treasures are practically unknown to the reading public of the West, notwithstanding the interest that has been taken in “things Japanese.
title: Plays of Old Japan: The 'No'
author: Stopes, Marie Carmichael, 1880-1958 [Translator]; Sakurai, Joji, 1858-1939 [Translator]

quoteFirst: Yet the river itself is cribbed within far narrower bounds than when the first huts of savage fishermen were stuck upon the reed-beds of the marsh; for the town was first set upon islets that have long ago been absorbed into the mainland, and the waters of the Seine once washed the boatmen's landing stages at a spot that now bounds the Parvis of the Cathedral. Even now the Seine varies in breadth at this point from a hundred and
quoteLast: hundred and fifteen metres, with a depth of five metres on the quays at lowest tide. These tides are felt as far as twenty miles above the town.
title: The Story of Rouen
author: Cook, Theodore Andrea, 1867-1928; Cook, Jane E. (Jane Elizabeth), 1836-1920 [Illustrator]; James, Helen M. (Helen Mary), 1863-1900 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The screw had been shipped, and the whole power of the machinery collected on the capstan would have quickly drawn the apparatus on board. The descent began at
quoteTime: twenty-five minutes past one at night
quoteLast: , and the chamber, drawn under by the reservoirs full of water, disappeared from the surface of the ocean.
title: From the Earth to the Moon, Direct in Ninety-Seven Hours and Twenty Minutes: and a Trip Round It
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Hildibrand, Henri Théophile, 1824-1897 [Engraver]; Bayard, Émile Antoine, 1837-1891 [Illustrator]; Neuville, Alphonse Marie de, 1835-1885 [Illustrator]
